There are several recent examples of collaborations amongst countries to tackle global issues. Here are some examples of successful collaborations:

1. COVAX: The COVID-19 Vaccines Global Access Facility (COVAX) is a global collaboration to ensure equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines. It is co-led by the World Health Organization (WHO), Gavi, The Vaccine Alliance, and the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI). As of September 2021, COVAX has delivered over 258 million vaccine doses to more than 140 countries.

2. Montreal Protocol: The Montreal Protocol is an international agreement to protect the ozone layer by phasing out the production of ozone-depleting substances (ODSs). It was signed by 197 countries in 1987. Since then, the ozone hole over Antarctica has been gradually shrinking, and the Protocol is credited as one of the most successful environmental agreements.

3. The Paris Agreement: The Paris Agreement is an international treaty to combat climate change. It was signed in 2015 by 197 countries and aims to limit the global temperature rise to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels. Many countries have made commitments to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions under the Agreement.

4. The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria: The Global Fund is a partnership between governments, civil society, and the private sector to accelerate the end of the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, and malaria. Since its inception in 2002, it has disbursed over $50 billion to support programs in more than 100 countries.

5. The International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA): IRENA is an intergovernmental organization that supports countries in the transition to a sustainable energy future. It has over 160 member countries and works to promote renewable energy technologies and policies.

These collaborations have been successful to varying degrees. For example, COVAX has successfully delivered millions of vaccine doses to various countries. The Montreal Protocol has led to a reduction in the production and use of harmful ozone-depleting substances. However, there are also challenges in implementing these agreements, and some countries have not fully committed to the goals of the agreements they have signed. Nonetheless, such collaborations are essential in tackling global issues and ensuring a sustainable future for all.
